story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe daily newspaper Sabah&nbsppurports to publish the names, photos and travel movements of 15 Saudi nationals it says arrived in Istanbul just hours before the Washington Post journalist disappearedClick to followThe IndependentA Turkish newspaper has published the names, faces, and travel movements of what it describes as the 15 Saudis allegedly involved in the disappearance of a prominent journalist who vanished in Istanbul last week. Then, online sleuths reportedly managed to use open-source material to identify at least eight of those allegedly involved in the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi, a 59-year-old Saudi journalist, as members of Saudi security forces. One photo purported to show a member of the 15-member team hobnobbing with Mohammed bin Salman, the powerful 33-year-old Saudi crown prince who has become the primary target of&nbspMr Khashoggi’s criticisms. Another identified an alleged team member as Salah Mohammed al-Tubaigy, a name and face matching the head of forensic evidence at Saudi’s General Security department.Sabah purports to identify the 15-member Saudi team allegedly involved in the disappearance of journalist Jamal KhashoggiThe details&nbspwere published by Sabah, a mass-circulation daily newspaper close to the government of president Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Friends, family, and officials say Mr Khashoggi was lured to the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on 2 October before disappearing.&nbspTurkish media reported that security camera footage from inside the consulate was removed and that staff were ordered to go home the afternoon Mr Khashoggi arrived.On the same day, two private jets, owned by Riyadh based Sky Prime Aviation,&nbspreportedly arrived from Saudi Arabia to Istanbul’s Ataturk airport, carrying the 15 personnel, landing just hours before Mr Khashoggi’s scheduled appointment at the consulate. Some of the 15 checked in to the five-star&nbspMovenpick&nbsphotel near the Saudi consulate in Istanbul’s Levent district.&nbspBoth private jets and the 15 men departed hours later, according to Turkish officials and local press. Khashoggi: Emergence of Saudi dissident and his potentially tragic endTurkish authorities investigating the disappearance of Mr Khashoggi, a prominent Saudi with Turkish ethnic roots, have been leaking information about the probe to local and international media with what appears to be the tacit approval of government officials.Police in Istanbul have formed a special team to investigate Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance, the newspaper Milliyet reported, tasked specifically to use chemicals, dogs, and infrared light to look for DNA, blood and other traces of the journalist at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul.The Post and other media also circulated a photo, likely taken from security camera footage, showing a black Mercedes Vito van that was parked outside the consulate and left shortly after Mr Khashoggi’s arrival, parked in front of the residence of Saudi consul general Mohammad al-Otaibi.The 15-member team identified by Sabah are all Saudi men aged between 30 and 57 years old. Those purportedly tracked down via open source internet tools by Oslo-based researcher Iyad al-Baghdadi and others include: a Saudi special forces member a lieutenant colonel in the Saudi civil defence force a major and lieutenant in the Saudi air force a lieutenant in the service guarding the crown prince’s palace and an intelligence service colonel who had once been attached to the Saudi embassy in the UK.Kalin on the disappearance of a Saudi journalist Jamal KhashoggiMr Khashoggi served for years as the right-hand man of Saudi prince Turki bin Faisal, a former intelligence chief as well as Riyadh’s envoy to the US and UK.&nbspIncreasingly frustrated with Saudi Arabia’s&nbspcourse, he began to bristle at the restrictions placed on media and civil society, eventually moving to the US last year amid fears for his own safety. In recent months he had grown increasingly critical of the crown prince, who has been criticised as authoritarian despite attempts to cast himself as a reformer. Saudi officials have denied that they had anything to do with Mr Khashoggi’s disappearance, insisting he left the consulate, but without providing proof, as demanded by Mr Erdogan.&nbspThe disappearance of Mr Khashoggi, a permanent US resident, has put Washington in a tough spot. The crown prince has forged a strong alliance with the administration&nbspof Donald Trump and a personal bond with the US president’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner. US lawmakers have made tough statements about the Khashoggi affair, but the White House and State Department have been tepid. Saudi Arabia has vowed to buy $110bn in American weapons.“We’re not going to make any judgments about what had happened to him,” Heather Nauert, State Department spokeswoman, told reporters on Tuesday. “The United States is certainly concerned about his whereabouts. Senior officials at the State Department have spoken with Saudi officials through diplomatic channels about the matter. We call on the government of Saudi Arabia to conduct a thorough and transparent investigation.” Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?Anyone can post in open comments. story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options'If this goes unpunished, it means that every tyrant in this bloody region has a licence to kill his opponents anywhere and everywhere. Anyone could do anything if this becomes the norm'Click to followThe IndependentAbdul-Rahman Ayyash had gone abroad to to help Syrians escaping that country’s war, planning to return home soon&nbspto Egypt and his family. But then Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi&nbsptightened his hold on the country, killing hundreds of anti-government protesters on the streets, and jailing many of Mr Ayyash’s friends. A two-week trip turned into five often painful years of exile. The 28-year-old missed out on his sister’s marriage, his niece’s birth, his father’s long illness, and days spent with his childhood friends in his home town, the Nile Delta city of Mansoura. He eked out a living as a journalist and researcher in Istanbul, gaining a name for himself as a thoughtful critic of Mr Sisi’s human rights violations and corruption. Now, following what is widely feared to be the brutal assassination in Istanbul of a leading Saudi exile journalist Jamal Khashoggi, Mr Ayyash again fears for his safety. “When I think about Jamal, he was doing exactly what I’m doing —&nbsptravelling around to conferences, writing in Arabic and English,” said Mr Ayyash. He&nbspmet repeatedly with Mr Khashoggi, who is missing and feared dead following a 2 October visit to the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. “For everyone in my circle, Jamal’s case is the only thing we are talking about,” he said. “The worst thing we thought might happen is we would go into our embassy or consulate, and they would harass us somehow, maybe take our passports. Our imagination never reached the&nbsppoint that we could be abducted and killed in our own embassy.Sabah purports to identify the 15-member Saudi team allegedly involved in the disappearance of journalist Jamal KhashoggiMr Khashoggi’s disappearance -- possibly at the hands of a 15-member team that arrived in Istanbul from Riyadh shortly before his disappearance and headed abroad quickly afterward&nbsp—&nbsphas terrified and traumatised many other Middle East activists, journalists, dissidents, and scholars who were forced to flee their countries. “We’re all a target now,” said Joseph Bahout, a French-Lebanese scholar who is often critical of Syrian ruler Bashar al-Assad. He spoke from Beirut,&nbspwhere he frequently travels and which remains an area contested by allies of&nbspSaudi Arabia and its rival Iran. “If this goes unpunished, it means that every tyrant in this bloody region has a licence to kill his opponents anywhere and everywhere. Anyone could do anything if this becomes the norm.”Unnamed Turkish and US&nbspofficials have described Mr&nbspKhashoggi’s disappearance as a probable&nbspassassination. It wouldn't be&nbspthe first such incident in a&nbspregion rife with armed conflict, bombings, and clandestine shadow wars. Libya’s Muammar Gaddafi and Iraq’s Saddam Hussein had few compunctions about gunning down outspoken critics abroad. Iran appears to have begun to ramp up a decades-old practice of assassinating dissidents in exile. An Iranian activist in the The Hague and an Iranian-British satellite television executive in Istanbul were among those shot dead under unexplained circumstances over the last couple of years. Salman&nbspwith Donald Trump in Washington this year (Reuters)But those counties all acquired pariah status, whilst oil-rich Saudi Arabia remains a member of the international community in good standing. Next week, US&nbsptreasury secretary Steve Mnuchin and the CEOs of JP Morgan Chase and Uber are scheduled to attend a forum in Saudi Arabia hosted by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who has been accused by US&nbspintelligence officials of ordering Mr Khashoggi's abduction. Saudi Arabia has also repeatedly abducted dissident members of the royal family, dragging them back to the kingdom against their will.&nbspSaudi officials insist Mr Khashoggi&nbspleft the embassy shortly after he arrived, a narrative contradicted by reams of security camera footage leaked by Turkish officials to local and international media.&nbsp“Gaddafi used to do such things and paid a high price,” said Yahia Assiri, a Saudi dissident in London, and a good friend of Mr Khashoggi. “If this things goes and Saudi doesn’t pay a price, so many countries around the world will copy this. It it will become a precedent.”He added: “The very important thing is that those dictators are copying each other. They learn from each other.”Mr Khashoggi, at one point a Saudi insider, fled his country for the US&nbsplast year. He&nbspbegan to carve out a career for himself as a writer and commentator, critical of the&nbsprise of Crown Prince Mohammed. Since coming to power and serving as the de factor ruler of the country under his father, King Salman, the&nbspSaudi crown prince&nbsphas launched a series of economic and social reforms lauded by the West. But he has also jailed dissidents of all stripes, and occasionally targeted&nbspoutspoken critics abroad.&nbspMr Khashoggi&nbspwent to the Saudi consulate in Istanbul to obtain paperwork to settle personal matters, a run-of-the-mill procedure for many people living abroad including expatriates, refugees and migrant labourers who must seek consular assistance&nbspfor renewing passports, registering births, certifying marriages, and completing university applications. Mr Ayyash said he had no fears when he last visited the Egyptian consulate in Istanbul four years ago, but will think twice if he must go&nbspagain now. He noted that Mr Khashoggi maintained cordial ties with Prince Khalid bin Salman, the Saudi ambassador to Washington and brother of the Crown Prince, a relationship that apparently offered him no protection. ”It’s a very grave situation, if it could happen in a consulate,” said Yasin Aktay, an adviser to Turkey’s ruling Justice and Development Party and a friend of Mr Khashoggi. There have&nbspto be consequences.The scholar, who asked for her name to be withheld, said Mr Khasoggi's&nbspdisappearance&nbsphad profoundly affected her and others feelings about their&nbsphomeland. Every job offer from back home, every invitation to a conference, or outreach from a government official&nbsphas become fraught. We shift between feelings of never wanting to go back, to fearing we will never be able to go back, she said. There is a deep hurt or pain that occurs when your&nbspgovernment rejects you,&nbspwhen all you wanted to do is make things better.The uproar over the incident, and the public relations damage it has inflicted on&nbspSaudi, could make leaders wary of any such violence in the future. The Saudi leadership is clearly rattled by the international reaction to the alleged abduction, which it strenuously denies. But&nbspas one of the world’s top&nbspoil exporters and arms importers,&nbspSaudi Arabia is also in a unique geopolitical position.“It increases the incentives and desires for crazed, power-obsessed rules-free people like Sisi to think they can get away with it,” said Sarah Leah Whitson, Middle East director of Human Rights Watch. “But nobody but Saudi has the carte blanche.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: Meghan Markle news Prince Harry Royal tour Fiji elections rejected delay Commonwealth
story: The Royal couple are set to embark on a 16-day tour of Australia, New Zealand, Tonga and Fiji, arriving in Sydney on Monday October 15 ahead of the 2018 Sydney Invictus Games in support of wounded servicemen and women.The couple&rsquos imminent visit to Fiji has nevertheless caused concern among political commentators, who have warned it could interfere in the country&rsquos general election, which will take place within 20 days of the couple&rsquos visit.Robin Nair, Fiji&rsquos former foreign affairs permanent secretary, told ABC: &ldquoThe perception is, of course, that the Fijian government will take full advantage of the visit.&ldquoFijians love the Royals, and the government knows that there will be great euphoria and joy created by the visit.                Meghan Markle&rsquos ex marries heiress RICHER than Prince Harry                Will Meghan Markle and Prince Harry MISS Princess Eugenie&rsquos wedding? The former official lambasted the British High Commission in the country&rsquos capital Suva for not delaying the visit.He said: &ldquoI would have thought the British High Commission in Suva would have advised the Commonwealth office in London about the forthcoming elections and the environment in which the elections are taking place.&ldquoIt&rsquos not the right timing.Mr Nair&rsquos concerns were echoed by Shailendra G Raju, a government critic and aide to two former prime ministers, who also called on the visit to be &ldquopostponed to a mutually convenient and more appropriate time.Meghan and Harry's visit to Fiji has been criticised due to its proximity to the country's elections (Image: )Meghan Markle and Prince Harry are expected to meet Fiji's Prime Minister Voreqe Bainimarama (Image: )Meghan and Harry will spend two days on Fiji during their tour of Oceania (Image: )Mr Nair and Mr Raju&rsquos concerns were nevertheless rejected by the British High Commission, which insisted that the Royal couple&rsquos visit will remain apolitical.A spokesman for the High Commission said: &ldquoTheir programme will be non-political and support bilateral relations between the two countries.&ldquoGiven that Their Royal Highnesses are visiting Australia, New Zealand, and Tonga next month, it makes sense for a visit to Fiji to take place at the same time.Associate Professor Giselle Bastin from Flinders University in Australia also noted that members of the British Royal Family typically meet with leaders from varying political parties while undertaking Royal tours.                Royal charmer: Prince Harry should have special DIPLOMATIC ROLE                Royal SCANDAL: King George V RUTHLESSLY knifed Tsar Nicholas in backMeghan and Harry will attend the 2018 Invictus Games in Sydney to start their tour (Image: )Meghan and Harry will visit Melbourne in the lead-up to state elections in Victoria (Image: )She told ABC: &ldquoThey meet the Premier of the day but there&rsquos usually the leader of the opposition party hovering in the background somewhere, so they make sure they meet or confront both sides.&ldquoIt will be built into their itinerary that they are at least exposed to people from the various political persuasions.The Duke and Duchess&rsquo visit to Melbourne will also be in the immediate lead-up to state elections in Victoria, which are taking place on November 24.

title: princess eugenie wedding time what time royal wedding october 12
story: Pre-wedding nerves may be kicking in for Princess Eugenie and her husband-to-be Jack Brooksbank as the big day is mere hours away.Eugenie has been with fianc&eacute Jack for eight years, after meeting him on a skiing trip through mutual friends.&nbspFor the second royal wedding of the year, the Princess has chosen the same venue as cousin Prince Harry&rsquos nuptials to Meghan Markle in May this year.&nbspThe chosen church, St George&rsquos Chapel, sits in the grounds of Windsor Castle in the town of Windsor.&nbsp                Princess Eugenie wedding 2018: What will Eugenie wear?                 Camilla beams in tartan ahead of royal wedding SNUB What time is Princess Eugenie&rsquos wedding?&nbspWhilst guests will be arriving from 10am, Princess Eugenie will make her entrance just before 11am for the ceremony to begin on the hour.&nbspLasting for approximately an hour, the Dean of Windsor, David Connor will officiate the wedding whilst John Sentamu, the Archbishop of York will lead prayers.&nbspAfter the ceremony, the newlyweds will take to a carriage for a procession out of Windsor Castle grounds and into the town.&nbspThousands are expected in Windsor tomorrow to see Eugenie and Jack marry (Image: )Royal fans will be able to see the couple pass through Castle Gate and travel along Windsor High Street, before returning back to the castle via the Cambridge Gate.On the couple&rsquos return, the Queen will then host a reception in Windsor Castle for the 850 invited guests.Later, a black-tie reception will be held at the Royal Lodge, the home of Eugenie&rsquos father - the Duke of York, Prince Andrew.&nbspThe Royal Lodge is located in Windsor Great Park, Berkshire, approximately three miles south of Windsor Castle.                Kate's wedding dress: What will Duchess wear for Eugenie's wedding?The town of Windsor is preparing for Royal Wedding celebrations (Image: REUTERS)The Grade II listed property was home to the Queen Mother for more than 70 years until her death in 2002.Prince Andrew was then granted a 75-year lease of the Georgian House in 2003.&nbspThe second day of celebrations will be held at the Royal Lodge, however, will be a much more relaxed affair than the night before.&nbspThe guests will return to the 17th-century property and its 51-acre grounds for a funfair-themed celebration.The pair will marry in St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle  (Image: )A royal source told The Daily : After the more formal celebration at Windsor Castle, the Saturday bash will be a relaxed party.There will be dodgems and funfair rides, coconut shies, lots of food stalls, loads of cocktails, Bloody Marys for the hangovers and a festival vibe.For those wanting to watch the big day as it happens, ITV1 are broadcasting the ceremony live on This Morning at the Royal Wedding hosted by Eamonn Holmes and Ruth Langsford.&nbspThe programme will begin at 10am to give viewers the chance to witness royal and celebrity guests arriving.

title: princess eugenie wedding jack brooksbank windsor rules mobile phone ban windsor
story: Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank have demanded wedding guests be seated by 10.30am (Image: )The couple sent guests an information pack in preparation for their big day in Windsor tomorrow. Guests have been asked to meet at a farm shop ahead of the service and to surrender phones so no snaps of the service are shared on social media.The strict policy is also understood to contain more detailed information on how the ceremony will unfold, such as what time A-list attendees can expect to see the Queen and other members of the Royal Family take their seats.According to Vanity Fair, 28-year-old Eugenie, granddaughter to the Queen, and Mr Brooksbank, 32, asked guests to meet at the Farm Shop in Windsor where a fleet of minibuses will transport them to the chapel for 10.15am.The specially-prepared pamphlet says no photography whatsoever is allowed inside St George&rsquos Chapel, which is the same location where cousin Prince Harry and former Suits actress Meghan Markle wed five months ago in May.                Princess Eugenie wedding: Royal spotted in rumoured &pound1,000 outfit                Princess Eugenie tiara: What is the York tiara? Will Eugenie wear it?After the wedding, the star-studded congregation will then make their way on foot to Windsor Castle where the Queen will host a reception.The document says guests should &ldquosurrender mobile telephones, cameras, and any electronic devices used for image capture on arrival at the Queen&rsquos bash.Prince Harry and Meghan also had a no-phones policy for their Windsor wedding despite a handful of images making their way onto social media and subsequently doing the rounds on the internet afterwards.Also included in the couple&rsquos rulebook are the timings of the huge day, which is expected to cost around &pound2million in police operations and security to protect the couple and their flurry of guests.The couple sent guests an information pack in preparation for their big da (Image: )At 10.15am sharp the congregation are expected to be seated at the chapel.Between 10.25am and 10.55am members of the Royal Family and Mr Brooksbank&rsquos family are expected to arrive ahead of Eugenie, who will be accompanied by her father Prince Andrew, the Duke of York.At 11am the service will begin and will last for around 55 minutes.At 12.10pm Eugenie and Mr Brooksbank will undertake a 15-minute carriage procession around Windsor to delight royal fans before walking on foot to Windsor Castle for a reception.                How Princess Eugenie&rsquos wedding will echo Sarah Ferguson&rsquos                Princess Eugenie wedding dress odds REVEALED: 'We are in for a TREAT'The Queen&rsquos reception will end at 3.30pm and everybody will make their way to Royal Lodge for the couple&rsquos second reception hosted by the Duke of York and his ex-wife - mother to the bride Sarah Ferguson.Names of those taking part were yesterday released by the family, with Prince George and six-year-old Louis de Givenchy, son of Frenchman Olivier de Givenchy, a JP Morgan banker, enlisted as page boys.Bridesmaids will be led by Princess Charlotte and will also include Robbie Williams and Ayda Field&rsquos daughter Theodora, six, as well as sisters Savannah, seven, and Isla Philips, six, four-year-old Mia Tindall and Maud Windsor, five, granddaughter of Prince Michael of Kent.

title: Brexit news Theresa May UK EU customs union ITV Peston
story: The astonishing claim was made on ITV Peston, the current affairs show, during an interview with former Brexit Secretary David Davis.Mr Peston said: &ldquoI have it from very good sources that last night Olly Robbins and his opposite number who works for Michel Barnier agreed to an outline of a deal which would keep the UK in the customs union for the period that a so-called backstop would have to operate.Olly Robbins is Theresa May&rsquos top Brexit advisor and is seen as the architect of her controversial Chequers plan.A backstop deal would come into effect if the UK and EU can&rsquot reach a full agreement finalising their future relations.                Spain in Brexit PANIC as tourist boss warns of no deal DISASTER                Brexit DILEMMA: May faces unionist REVOLT if she agrees to EU demandsUnless it is time limited it could theoretically see the UK stuck in the customs union indefinitely.Mr Davis, who resigned from the Government in July in protest at Theresa May&rsquos Chequers deal, made it clear on the programme such an agreement is unacceptable.He said: &ldquoNo I don&rsquot approve it in the terms you&rsquore talking about because there&rsquos no backstop to the backstop.&ldquoThere&rsquos no limit to the backstop, it only ceases when the EU agrees to it.&ldquoNo I don&rsquot approve it because there&rsquos no backstop to the backstop (Image: ITV PESTON)&ldquoThere&rsquos no limit to the backstop, it only ceases when the EU agrees to it (Image: )&ldquoWhy should we ever agree?The European customs union is a free trade area which also maintains common tariffs on non-members.As such, duties are not paid on trade between members, but are charged at a common rate to other countries.                Brexit uncertainty has mixed affect on housing market across the UK&ldquoWhy should we ever agree? (Image: )All trade agreements are made by the European Commission, essentially the Government of the European Union.Members states are consequently unable to make their own trade deals.Should the UK stay in the customs union it would see the European Commission negotiate trade deals on behalf of the UK, despite the UK losing its European Commission representation after Brexit.&ldquoIn the referendum both sides said &lsquoLeave&rsquo meant leaving the customs union and single market (Image: )Yesterday former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson claimed staying in the customs union would turn the UK into a &ldquopermanent EU colony.He added: &ldquoThis is far from take back control.&ldquoIn the referendum both sides said &lsquoLeave&rsquo meant leaving the customs union and single market.

title: Brexit news Daniel Hannan second eu referendum people s vote campaign labour
story: Mr Hannan, Conservative MEP for the South East, made the dramatic claim during an interview with&nbspExpress.Speaking of a second referendum he said: &ldquoI think there is a huge risk, it would be very clear what had happened.&ldquoThe country would have voted, more people would have voted for Brexit than have ever voted for anything, and their political elites would have overturned the result.&ldquoThat, quite apart from it being a bad outcome on Europe, would be catastrophic for the legitimacy and authority of our system.                &lsquoWe can&rsquot give the EU &pound39billion for NOTHING&rsquo warns David Davis The self-styled &lsquoPeople&rsquos Vote&rsquo campaign, which is backed by some Labour, Liberal Democrat and Conservative MPs, is campaigning for a second referendum on whatever deal Theresa May negotiates.The Labour Party has said it could back such a referendum if it can&rsquot bring down the Government and force a general election.Sir Keir Starmer, Labour&rsquos shadow Brexit Secretary, went further telling his party&rsquos conference last month &ldquonobody is ruling out remain as an option in a second vote.However, Mr Hannan explained to&nbspExpress&nbspa second vote could destabilise the UK. (Image: )&ldquoBritain has until now been a country with a very high level of trust in politics (Image: )He argued: &ldquoBritain has until now been a country with a very high level of trust in politics.&ldquoI know that may sound funny but what I mean is people don&rsquot question the outcome of elections, we&rsquove never had a dictatorship and we&rsquove never had a revolution.&ldquoPeople agree to the rules and stick to them in a way that is not true of every country.Mr Hannan admitted he worries a second referendum would finish these conventions.He noted many of those &ldquowho were loudest in insisting that there would only be one vote, the Nick Clegg&rsquos and the John Major&rsquos, are the same people who are now considering a second referendum.                May&rsquos Brexit negotiations LAMBASTED by pro-EU ex-ambassador&ldquoIf they now turn around and went back on that commitment I think it would be a crisis of democracy (Image: )He said: &ldquoIf they now turn around and went back on that commitment I think it would be a crisis of democracy.Many of the key People&rsquos Vote campaign supporters, who include Liberal Democrat leader Vince Cable, Labour MP David Lammy and Tory MP Anna Soubry, were prominent &lsquoRemain&rsquo backers in 2016.The same was true of celebrity backers like actor Tony Robinson and ex-footballer Gary Lineker.Mr Hannan went on to discuss why, in his view, some politicians are unable to accept the referendum defeat.He asserted: &ldquoI think it was the psychological shock of not getting their way on something.&ldquoI think it was the psychological shock of not getting their way on something (Image: )&ldquoThey are accustomed to politics having happened within certain parameters and in June 2016 those parameters were blown away.&ldquoDuring the campaign Remainers decided the Leave case was reactionary, small-minded, anti-immigration and so on.&ldquoBy polling day I think they&rsquod come to believe their own propaganda.Daniel Hannan has been a fervent Eurosceptic campaigner for decades making the case for Brexit via books, articles and public debates.He was one of the founders of Vote Leave, the successful pro-Brexit campaign which won the June 2016 referendum.

title: Brexit news EU UK latest Nick Clegg vote no deal European Union Viktor Orban
story: The interview got rather heated when the former Lib Dem leader claimed the world has changed &ldquodramatically since the 2016 Brexit vote when 17.4million British people voted to leave the European Union.Speaking on ITV&rsquos Peston, Mr Clegg said: &ldquoWe didn&rsquot on the 23 June 2016 know it was going to be costly or as complex or as drawn out as it clearly is going to be. What&rsquos happened to all of those promises?&ldquoThose Utopian promises that people were given in the summer. They have disappeared like the evaporating morning mist. So, in other words, I think one of the great things about a democracy, unlike an autocracy, is that you can move with the times and confront new facts.But the ITV host hit back and pointed out key issues with the EU. Mr Peston said: &ldquoNo but hang on. I&rsquom asking you a different question. I was asking you about the EU. They are pulling off in a very chauvinist direction.But Peston fired back and ripped into the Remainer argument. He said: &ldquoSo, why do you want to be associated closely with somebody like Orb&aacuten whose politics are completely antithetical to yours?In response, Mr Clegg said: &ldquoBecause I am not like a Utopian Brexiteer who claims that money is going to fall from the sky the moment we leave Brussels. I accept the European Union is an imperfect organisation &ndash&nbspof course it is.&ldquoBut I think it has done a great to intrench peace and prosperity on our patchwork continent.Mr Clegg has continually called for Britain to have a so-called &lsquoPeople&rsquos Vote&rsquo on the final Brexit deal.The self-styled &lsquoPeople&rsquos Vote&rsquo campaign, which is backed by some Labour, Liberal Democrat and Conservative MPs, is campaigning for a second referendum on whatever deal Theresa May negotiates.Demands for a People&rsquos Vote was shut down by Brexiteer Daniel Hannan during an interview with Express.Speaking of a second referendum he said: &ldquoI think there is a huge risk, it would be very clear what had happened.&ldquoThe country would have voted, more people would have voted for Brexit than have ever voted for anything, and their political elites would have overturned the result.&ldquoThat, quite apart from it being a bad outcome on Europe, would be catastrophic for the legitimacy and authority of our system.

story: Tony Blair was asked whether he felt at all responsible for the Brexit vote and for Jeremy Corbyn no leading the Labour Party.Ending freedom of movement was a key issue debated during the 2016 EU referendum.Former Prime Minister Mr Blair has been criticised the decisions his Government took following eastern European countries joining the European Union in 2004.At the Reuters event, audience member Costas Pitas, asked: &ldquoDo you feel at all partly responsible for either Brexit or for Jeremy Corbyn&rsquos leadership.                'Brexit no longer has support of people': Pimlico Plumbers boss SLA...                Brexit mess: May tries to buy time on Barnier&rsquos customs union fudge&ldquoCorbyn because so many people who voted for him saw it as taking the party back from what they consider to be the betrayal of New Labour.&ldquoAnd Brexit because to take one example, immigration was a huge issue in that vote, and obviously during your premiership, immigration rose and people remember the predictions that ended up being much lower than the realities.Tony Blair replied: &ldquoI am aware that it is always a good thing to blame me literally for everything.&ldquoFor my perspective, to be blamed for Brexit when I neither supported the referendum or supported Brexit is a little bit tribal unreasonable, I would say.&ldquoAnd I would say I oppose Jeremy Corbyn being made Labour Party leader, but I understand why you are asking the question.&ldquoJust on the first thing, as I always say to people I am very happy to take responsibility for the decisions that I took for my time as Prime Minister.&ldquoBut, I am not taking responsibility for the time after I left because I wasn&rsquot in charge.He added: &ldquoJust to take an example, on the inter-european migration, yes our estimates turned out to be wrong. In 2004 we were in a different economic position all together.Tony Blair responded after being asked if he was to blame for Brexit (Image: REUTERS&bull)&ldquoBy the way, people came because we needed them to come. And if I had still been in office, say in 2008 to 2009 post financial crash and you were noticing real problems within the community around these questions.&ldquoThe irony is about this whole immigration from Europe position is that there are masses of things that Britain could do if it wanted to restrict that immigration.&ldquoThe truth is, successive government&rsquos decided that they didn&rsquot want to.When asked whether Jeremy Corbyn could become Prime Minister, Mr Blair said: &ldquoOf course.Mr Blair also urged Labour MPs to &ldquohold firm against Brexit suggesting voting down Mrs Mays deal in Parliament brings back the hope of forcing another referendum.&ldquoI would advise them to hold firm against Brexit because either of these choices are unpalatable, he said.&ldquoIf there is no way round this dilemma then you are going to come back with a deal that is going to be unpalatable for one of two reasons - either because people will say 'what on earth is the point of having Brexit if you are still bound by the rules?'&ldquoOn the other hand, if you come back with what is essentially a Canada-style free-trade agreement that is going to do immense damage because you are going to have to recreate and restructure your relationships.

We have an enormous debt to our Armed Forces in this country.CUCA claimed students were trying to &ldquoerase history.Remembrance Day poppies could glorify war, students said (Image: )Tony Blair, Jeremy Corbyn and John Major at London's Remembrance Sunday service at The Cenotaph (Image: )Chairman Timur Coskun said he wanted more promotion of Remembrance Day as many students do not wear poppies.A student union spokesman said: &ldquoDiscussions were not about erasing the past but broadening the focus of remembrance to include those who suffered and died wherever they were in the world.Undergraduate and postgraduate students will still lay wreaths at a Remembrance Sunday event.The motion comes as a Silent Soldier &lsquoTommy&rsquo was decapitated for a second time in a Welsh village.Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge, and Sophie, the Countess of Wessex (Image: )The memorial in Bargoed has been installed as part of a nationwide project to educate young people and raise money for mental and physical treatment for today&rsquos veterans.Statues, which show the silhouette of a First World War soldier, have been installed across UK villages, towns and cities, as well as outside businesses.&nbspA war memorial in Clackmannanshire, Scotland, was also spray painted blue, and one in Sanquhar, Scotland was doused in paint.

title: Brexit news Michael Gove UK EU Theresa May European Union
story: Theresa May has vowed to stick by her controversial Brexit Chequers plan despite criticism from EU leaders and pro-Leave MPs.Earlier this week former Brexit Minister Steve Baker warned the Prime Minister that up to 40 MPs were willing to vote down her Brexit plan.Speaking on Sky News,&nbsp Environment Secretary outlined he thought there would be a Brexit deal, and it would be supported and pass through the House of Commons.Presenter Adam Boulton asked: &ldquoWhat do you reckon, deal or no deal, is it going to get through Parliament?                'Brexit SELF-HARM' Remainer peer launches attack on Brexiteers                Blair makes FEEBLE plea when confronted about Brexit &ndash 'I get blamed'&ldquoChequers, we&rsquore not allowed to say Chequers are we.Michael Gove was then pressed over whether he could say Chequers, to which the Conservative frontbencher obliged.He said: &ldquoI certainly will, Chequers.He added: &ldquoI think we will get a good deal and I think that Parliament will recognise a good deal is better than no deal.The bold claim from Mr Gove may surprise some Brexit supporters given the lack of support for the Prime Minister&rsquos Chequers plan.Speaking on the Today programme on Tuesday Mr Baker warned Theresa May about the number of Tory MPs who would vote down Chequers.He said: &ldquoI did a concrete canvas of colleagues when it was amendments to legislation and came up with the number nearly 80.&ldquoOf course, the Government are going to whip this vote extremely hard but what I would say is, whips would be doing incredibly well if they were to halve the numbers.&ldquoMy estimate is that there are at least 40 colleagues who are not going to accept a half-in, half-out Chequers deal. Or indeed a backstop that leaves us in the internal market and customs union come what may.Brexit news: Adam Boulton quizzed Michael Gove over whether there would be a Brexit deal (Image: SKYNEWS)Mrs May has repeatedly argued that the two Brexit options remaining for the UK include either Chequers or leaving with no deal.During the Sky News interview, Mr Gove also claimed the UK would be &ldquoreplenishing British waters after Brexit.He said: &ldquoIt is both about reviving our coastal communities but more effective conservation.&ldquoI think most people could concede that the Common Fisheries Policy has damaged Britain economy but it has also led to overfishing.&ldquoOur new fisheries bill will make it clear that we will be fishing in accordance with the principle of maximum sustainable yield, in other words we will be replenishing our waters.The Environment Secretary also outlined how Britain works side by side with European countries with environmental issues despite Brexit.Sky host Boulton said: &ldquoSome people might say better together.Mr Gove quickly replied: &ldquoWe are in many respects better together, but we are in many respects better as a self-governing nation, leading on the world stage, global Britain delivering a truly green Brexit.

story: Former Prime Minister Tony Blair claimed alternatives to voting down Theresa May's possible deal would be all worse as they would not result in a second Brexit referendum.Mr Blair suggested the Labour Party should not support the future agreement Mrs May secures with the European Union to create a blockade in Parliament.Asked whether his party should vote down the Brexit deal, the former Labour leader told Reuters: It really is difficult. The alternatives are all worse because if you do get to a blockage in parliament that is what opens up the possibility of going back to the people.My view is this only happens if there is a blockage in parliament. But if there is a blockage in Parliament it is a very simple argument. You say look we have been two and a bit years trying to reach an agreement that works, parliament is blocked.                Farage reveals REAL reason he HAD to get back on campaign trail                Blair makes FEEBLE plea when confronted about Brexit &ndash 'I get blamed'Mr Blair insisted the lack of a parliamentary majority for any Brexit plan Mrs May manages to secure with Brussels meant Britain can still be stopped from leaving the EU.He continued: I still believe it is possible that Brexit is stopped, I think there is no majority in parliament for any proposition that the prime minister brings back.If there is no way round this dilemma then you are going to come back with a deal that is going to be unpalatable for one of two reasons - either because people will say 'what on earth is the point of having Brexit if you are still bound by the rules?'On the other hand, if you come back with what is essentially a Canada-style free-trade agreement that is going to do immense damage because you are going to have to recreate and restructure your relationships.Brexit news: Mr Blair suggested Labour vote down the final Brexit deal to get a new vote (Image: REUTERS&bullBBC)Analysis carried out by Mr Blair&rsquos Institute for Global Change also claimed the UK&rsquos economy would take a 4.91 percent hit over 12 years if the UK crashed out of the EU without a deal, only marginally more than with Mrs May&rsquos Chequers proposal.Mr Blair warned the UK&rsquos services will be hit hardest, with the sector projected to fall by 2.1 percent in the event of &lsquono deal&rsquo, double the rate of goods exports.The NIESR report also indicated services would only be marginally better off under Mrs May&rsquos Chequers plan, as they are still projected to fall by 1.9 percent.The report from Mr Blair&rsquos institute, titled Brexit and the UK&rsquos Services Trade, revealed the UK&rsquos export of services to the EU rose in value from &pound70billion to &pound110billion between 2008 and 2017, an increase of 57 percent.

title: jeremy corbyn bristol visit colonialism teaching schools nick ferrari radio show
story: Nick Ferrari and Professor Hakim Adi, Professor of the History of Africa and the African Diaspora, engaged in an extremely heated argument on whether colonialism was &ldquosolely a crime.The pair were initially discussing Jeremy Corbyn&rsquos suggestion to change the way history is taught in schools before the debate took a more testy turn.The expert on African history declared: &ldquoThe way that young people are taught history is often in a very narrow way, so people don&rsquot really understand the world in which they live.&ldquoThey don&rsquot understand the full history of Britain and Britain&rsquos involvement in crimes against humanity, like colonialism and the trafficking of Africans for centuries and so on.                Britain shouldn't feel shame over colonial past there was good too                Blair makes DESPERATE plea for Labour to BLOCK Brexit forcing voteMr Ferrari questioned: &ldquoIs colonialism solely a crime then professor?To which Professor Hakim Adi responded: &ldquoI would say it was - was and is.The LBC host fired back: &ldquoRight, so the fact it stopped Indian widows being burnt on the death of their husband was a bad thing?Mr Adi sounded unsure: &ldquoUm, that was due to colonialism was it?Mr Ferrari blasted: &ldquoYes, I&rsquom sorry let me just check you&rsquore a professor of the history of Africa, yes my apologies, you must have known of that practice.&ldquoThat when the man died the widow was ceremonially burnt. The British military took over and stopped them.&ldquoYou seem to say that is a bad thing - I&rsquom rather surprised by that.The argument then took an even more heated turn with the professor threatening to &ldquoget his lawyers onto Ferrari for &ldquoputting words in his mouth.The LBC radio host asked the professor: But what about the Indian women? (Image: LBC)Earlier today, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn announced plans for a major reform of how history is taught in schools, during a speech delivered in Bristol.He argued black British history and the history of the British Empire, colonialism and slavery should be taught more extensively in school &ldquoto help ensure their legacy is more widely understood across the country.He said: &ldquoIt is vital that future generations understand the role that black Britons have played in our country&rsquos history and the struggle for racial equality.&ldquoIn the light of the Windrush scandal, 'black history' month has taken on a renewed significance and it is more important now than ever that we learn and understand as a society the role and legacy of the British Empire, colonisation and slavery.

story: Brexit news: Neolithic carved chalk cylinders, known as the Folkton Drums, (Image: PA )The ebb and flow of the UK&rsquos ancient ancestors' relationship with the continent will be unveiled in a new exhibition at a English Heritage's Making Connections exhibition in Stonehenge.The artefacts highlight the &ldquomaking and breaking of relations between the UK and Europe, with different periods of connection and relative isolation from our continental cousin.Objects in the display, which include prized items from the British Museum's collection of ancient Britain and Europe, range from a 6,500-year-old polished jade axe to an elaborate gold neck piece made around 4,000 years ago.In the early Neolithic period - before Stonehenge was built - mass migrations of people who were the first farmers and the earliest metal workers took place.                EU heading for &lsquoCRISIS&rsquo with Italy as budget threatens to tear euro...                Sarah Ferguson 'bag of nerves' ahead of showdown with PhilipIn the late Neolithic when Stonehenge was being constructed, communities were travelling and exchanging ideas from Orkney to southern England - but experts say there was little or no communication with continental Europe.Susan Greaney, English Heritage historian, said: From insular communities with what appears to be little outside communication, to mass migrations and the sharing of raw materials and finished artefacts, our ancestors have been making and breaking relationships with Continental Europe for thousands of years.Throughout the Neolithic and Bronze Age, Stonehenge stood at the centre of this constantly changing ebb and flow of objects, styles, people and ideas.Later came another period of connection with Europe, and the Beaker culture that brought Bronze Age technology to these shores 4,500 years ago was part of a migration that almost completely replaced the communities of Britain in just a few centuries.Brexit news: An early Neolithic jade axe, from near Canterbury (Image: PA )The exhibition opens with a jade axe made of stone from the Italian Alps, brought from continental Europe 1,500 years before Stonehenge was built, which would have been highly prized and connected people to their homelands.The following period of separation is represented by the 'Folkton drums', three chalk cylinders decorated with spirals and stylised faces dating from the late Neolithic around 3,000 BC and found in a child's burial site in North Yorkshire.Experts said the style of decoration on the drums is known from megalithic monuments, pottery and other items across Britain and Ireland but not further afield.A copper alloy sun disc dating from 1500 to 1300 BC and found in Ireland, which is thought to be part of a model chariot pulled by a ine horse, is going on display for the first time in living memory.                ROYAL FEUD: Camilla SNUBS Royal Wedding because of 'tensions with F...Brexit news: An early Bronze Age gold lunula (collar or neckpiece) (Image: PA )Brexit news: A copper alloy and oak flesh-hook, known as the Dunaverny flesh-hook from Dunaverny (Image: PA )Recently rediscovered in the British Museum store, it is of a type otherwise only known from continental Europe and shows that Bronze Age beliefs about how the sun and moon travelled across the sky were shared by people living across the region.The 4,000-year-old Blessington gold lunula, a beaten-gold crescent neck piece, also found in Ireland, shows that by 2,000 BC people were regularly exchanging metals over long distances.Though these kind of ornaments are almost exclusively found in Ireland and Britain, the motifs used to decorate them were drawn from European Beaker pottery and textiles, the experts said.A Bronze Age cup made of a single sheet of gold which shows close connections between southern England and northern France and flesh-hooks for lifting meat out of cauldrons and decorated with birds are also on display.Brexit news: A Bronze Age copper alloy 'sun disc', from Ireland (Image: PA )Neil Wilkin, British Museum curator, added: To be able to bring all these objects together for the first time at Stonehenge, one of the most important symbols of ancient Britain, is an exciting prospect.Neolithic and Bronze Age objects from the British Museum collections are displayed alongside artefacts borrowed from other lenders, including a Langdale axe from Wiltshire Museum, two carved chalk plaques from Salisbury Museum, and a Grooved Ware pot from Down Farm Museum in Dorset.

story: Hurricane Michael could make Florida&rsquos Red Tide issue even worse.Heavy rainfall from the deadly storm would increase runoff from agricultural areas and feed the toxic algae.Dr David Hastings, a professor of Marine Science and Chemistry at Eckerd College, told CBS News: &ldquoThe heavy rain will dilute farm and agriculture areas of all the nutrients, nitrates, phosphates and rain them into the beaches and coastal areas that serve to fertilise the red ride.&ldquoExactly what we don&rsquot want.                Hurricane Michael damage: Hurricane DESTROYS Florida as STORM hit                Hurricane Michael LIVE: NOAA puts Georgia and Carolinas on ALERTHowever, there is also the possibility that Hurricane Michael could help Florida&rsquos Red Tide problem.The two different scenarios depend&nbspon whether the battering storm brings more wind or rain.Dr David Hastings said: &ldquoThere are two possibilities.&ldquoThe hopeful one is that strong winds from the hurricane blow red tide offshore.Hurricane Michael: Red Tide devastates aquatic wildlife and causes respiratory problems for humans (Image: CBS News)The extremely harmful algae is currently spreading from Florida&rsquos Gulf Coast to Atlantic beaches for the first time in more than a decade.Beaches along the Gulf Coast are now being closed down by authorities due to the poisonous Red Tide bloom.The toxic mass has severe consequences for human and animal health.According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the Red Tide causes respiratory irritation for humans and kills fish, sea turtles, manatees, birds and dolphins.The poisonous fumes can make humans and their pets incredibly ill if inhaled, and is especially dangerous for those who are asthmatic.Red Tide is a type of algal bloom named Karenia Brevis.Algal blooms are essentially just large masses of small organisms named algae, which are take to the water and multiply en masse.Algae increase in both freshwater and saltwater environments, causing water discolouration.Mote Marine Laboratory and Aquarium says the Red Tide needs &ldquothe appropriate temperature, salinity, and nutrients it needs to grow and multiply.This means Red Tide is generally taking place in Florida due to a combination of different elements, including the right conditions and storms allowing the occurrence to take place.

story: Italy put forward plans to run a 2.4 percent of GDP deficit as part of the country&rsquos 2019 budget, triggering an immediate crackdown from the European Union.Matteo Salvini and top Eurocrats have exchanged insults since the proposal was made public, with Mr Salvini warning the bloc the Italian Government will retaliate to their threats.Former Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis told Bloomberg Mr Salvni's insistence to support the policy could edge the bloc closer to disintegration.Mr Varoufakis said: Mr Salvini, who is effectively the strong man behind the Government, his great wish is to disintegrate the European Union and for Italy to get out of the euro.                End of EU? Italian eurosceptic leader Salvini sees support DOUBLE                EU heading for &lsquoCRISIS&rsquo with Italy as budget threatens to tear euro...The establishment&rsquos insistence on policies that don&rsquot work in Italy is bringing the European Union closer and closer to disintegration.Despite threats to send the draft budget proposals back to Rome, Mr Salvini announced he would remain hard-nosed and refuse to come up with an alternative plan.&nbspMr Varoufakis, however, insisted the eurosceptic Italian Government should stop pursuing spoiled brat's policies and adopt a hard stance focused on changing the rules of the bloc.&nbspHe continued: Stop adopting the previous Government&rsquos strategy which I referred to, rather harshly, as the &lsquospoiled brat&rsquos syndrome&rsquo.EU news: Mr Varoufakis said Mr Salvini is edging Brussels closer to disintegration (Image: BLOOMBERG)If you want to be a serious Italian Prime Minister you want to be true to your own people and true to Europe.You should use your position as Prime Minister of Italy &ndash the third largest eurozone&rsquos economy &ndash in order to demand the European Union Council meets to discuss the rules and to discuss the reappraisal of these silly rules.Latest SWG polls of 1,500 Italians revealed support for Mr Salvini&rsquos Lega has nearly doubled, hitting 30.7 percent on October 8 in an apparent sign his demands for more support from the European Union have been met with the approval of Italian voters.Responding to the results of the latest polls on Wednesday, Mr Salvini said: I am proud of our government. Italians understand we are doing our best. We will make mistakes but we will do so with our own heads not because of someone else&rsquos orders.And with the European Elections scheduled for 2019, this week Mr Salvini reminded the Commission of the risks of threatening a core member state like Italy: The Europe of bankers, founded on mass immigration and economic insecurity, keeps on threatening and insulting Italians and their Government?Relax, in six months 500 million voters will fire them. story: An F-16 aircraft has exploded and caught fire at the Floreness airbase in Belgium (Image: @NewsExclusive)The aircraft was completely destroyed while a second F-16 was heavily damaged from the explosion.&nbspTwo people were wounded and treated at the scene.Injuries sustained were mainly related to hearing damage from the huge explosive noise.&nbspThe F-16 military aircraft caught fire near a hangar during routine ground maintenance.&nbsp                Russia accused of 'SABOTAGE' after explosion at Ukraine arms depotSome reports have claimed the jet ignited during a technical manoeuvre.&nbspSeveral explosions followed with plumes of thick black smoke filling the sky for miles around.&nbspFirefighters are being helped by civilian firefighters to tackle the blaze at the airbase.Around 30 men are involved in the operation, while several ambulances also arrived at the scene.The Floreness military airbase is home to F-16 Fighter Falcons (Image: )The military airfield is two miles southeast of Florennes, a Walloon municipality of southern Belgium.&nbspIt is home to the 2nd Tactical Wing, operating F-16 Fighter Falcons.&nbspUntil July 2009, the airbase was also home to the Tactical Leadership Programme, a joint training programme established by 10 NATO members.&nbspThis is a breaking story. title: medical marijuana uk legal treatment sativex
story: It remains largely illegal in the UK, although some forms do exist and can be prescribed by doctors or bought over the counter. Heres what you need to know.Marijuana, or cannabis, is the most consumed illegal drug in the UK.It is commonly ingested by smoking but for medical purposes it can also be taken in oil or pill form.Low concentration versions of cannabis oil are widely available in British pharmacies.Makers say it can be used to help promote sleep, boost appetite and reduce stress, anxiety and depression.Higher concentration forms of cannabis oil have been hailed for treating the symptoms of epilepsy, HIV and cancer.But cannabis oil with more than . per cent THC- the psychoactive element - is banned in the UK despite high-profile cases like Billy Caldwell.The -year-old was given a -day exemption to take higher strength cannabis oil to treat his severe epilepsy.In July  the governments Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs said the rules should be changed so doctors have the option of prescribing cannabis-derived products for certain ailments.It also recommended clinical trials to assess the safety and effectiveness of such products.It will be soon, yes.Medicinal marijuana will become available on prescription within the coming weeks after Home Office Secretary Sajid Javid agreed to relax drug laws.Medicinal cannabis will be available on prescription from next month, the Home Secretary announced today.Doctors will be able to prescribe cannabis products to patients from November .The new rules apply to England, Wales and Scotland, Sajid Javid said in a written statement.It follows several high-profile cases, including young epilepsy sufferers Alfie Dingley and Billy Caldwell, whose conditions appeared to be helped by cannabis oil.In order for a cannabis product to be considered medicinal it must meet three requirements: it needs to be a preparation or product which contains cannabis, cannabis resin, cannabinol or a cannabinol derivative it is produced for medicinal use in humans and is a medicinal product, or a substance or preparation for use as an ingredient of, or in the production of an ingredient of, a medicinal product, according to Mr Javids statement.Sativex is one of a very few drugs containing cannabis-derived THC and CBD  - another less potent ingredient - that can be prescribed on the NHS.It is used to relieve the pain of muscle spasms for sufferers of multiple sclerosis.Use of Sativex is currently limited to those people who respond to the first four weeks of treatment.However NICE, the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, does not recommend its prescription.In a  clinical guideline update, NICE said: The guidance does not recommend the use of the cannabinoid drug Sativex or fampridine as they provide only a modest benefit at a signicant cost to the NHS.Sativex costs £, per quality-adjusted le year , while fampridine costs in the region of £, per QALY.Both are well above NICE’s threshold of £, per QALY.

title: jean claude juncker everything wrong with eu
story: He is everything that’s wrong with the European project — and why it’s so vital that we leave.In his latest rant, he demanded “respect” and delivered a warning that “Press freedom has its limits”. Why Alas, Luxembourg’s finest is annoyed that the media keep reporting on the persistent rumours that he is half-cut most of the time.He must be to think, as he does, that the UK would have voted Remainonly HE had been involved in the referendum. Fat chance. He’d have doubled the Leave vote.The trials and tribulations of Brexit might have made some wonderit’s all worth the hassle. So it’s good of Jean-Claude, a puffed-up political pygmy, to remind us why we’re better off out.Brexiteers need to keep their eyes on the prize. Attention-seeking bores like Andrew Adonis and Alastair Campbell, plus shadowy campaign outfits, are trying their hardest to undermine Brexit.Nobody should think this battle is won. Nobody should be complacent about political battles still to come.And nobody who believes in a prosperous, independent nation should allow the perfect to be the enemy of the good when it comes to Britain’s departure, and walk into the Remainers’ “people’s vote” trap.We leave in less than six months. And when we do, we’ll raise a glass. Maybe Jean-Claude will join us.THE Universal Credit system IS a good idea – but the roll-out must be done properly.The Tories’ benefit changes in the last Government, making it more rewarding to be in work, are a big part of the ­reason employment is at a record high. UC is the final part of that puzzle.But reports that some working families could lose signicant amounts of cash overnight are deeply worrying.Our benefits regime needs to be firm.But it must also be fair.BOB Geldof warns Britain will be a ­“cultural jail” after Brexit.Quite why the power to strike our own trade deals will affect our ability to play guitar isn’t yet clear.In fact, when it comes to music, it’s Britain’s institutions that are more­ ­dangerous. The BBC has decided in its infinite wisdom to publish its entire archive of classical music to compete with streaming services and record labels. Why  Just because it can It’s a decision that sums up the big-state, God-complex thinking that seeps right through the BBC.Lord Hall promised to change Auntie’s tune – but he’s still hitting the wrong notesOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: house prices mortgages young people
story: All they are trying to do is the right thing. But this is the reality of trying to save up for a house.They work hard each month. They’d love to put something aside to save up for a home.But to live where there are good jobs, they have to spend so much on high rents that there’s nothing left over.So they can never save enough to break out of the cycle. No wonder they are frustrated.New figures show how bad things have got. The Institute for Fiscal Studies says four out of ten people in the  to -year-old age bracket couldn’t afford the mortgage on even the cheapest house in their area, eventhey had a deposit.The gap between prices and normal people’s earnings is just too big, because since  house prices in Britain have gone up more than in any other developed country.Expensive housing has meant that the proportion of young people on middle incomes who own their own home has collapsed: down from nearly two thirds  years ago, to just over a quarter today.We have to turn this round and restore home ownership.Many people feel they can’t get on and start a family until they have a nest of their own. Their lives are on hold.Politically it’s vital too. If young people don’t feel they’ve got a chance to get on in le, they are more likely to gamble and vote for extreme, disastrous politicians like Jeremy Corbyn.Even younger people who are earning decent wages feel squeezed, because they face a combination of high house prices and chunky repayments on their student loans.The Prime Minister is acutely aware of this. That’s why she’s set up a review of student fees, and moved to make housing her Number  priority other than Brexit.Hence her announcement of massive funding to build more affordable housing for people on lower incomes. But there’s much more to do.Building more homes for people to buy is a big part of the answer. Since  we have built only half as many houses as France each year, and so house prices have gone up twice as fast.Some people say building more means we must tear up the planning system and concrete over the countryside.But we know that approach won’t work. When Gordon Brown was PM we tried setting each area massive housing targets. All those targets built was resentment. We need a smarter approach to tackle the reasons people often oppose new housing.We build in the wrong places. Instead of tacking on new estates to existing towns and villages without enough new school places or parking places, let’s get back into the business of building planned new cities and towns.Let’s build upwards in our city centres with taller buildings, rather than just sprawling cities outwards.What drives people mad is seeing developers make massive windfall profits when they get planning permission, but then not sharing those benefits with local residents.Imagine instead,new houses being built next door always paid for people in neighbouring streets to get cheap homes for their children to buy. People would feel much better about development.Restoring the dream of home ownership isn’t just about building more houses though.We need to think about the balance of rented properties and home ownership. Over the last ten years we’ve built many new homes each year, but the number of homeowners fell. How come The reason is that the number of properties being snapped up by buy-to-let landlords has grown faster than we have built new ones.Don’t get me wrong. Landlords, who have themselves worked hard, weren’t doing anything wrong.Butwe want to get home ownership growing again we need to encourage savers to put their money into shares and into growing businesses rather than just bidding up the price of houses. The think tank Onward proposed this week that we should offer a tax break to landlords who sell their homes to their tenants.This “Chance to Buy” would be a bit like the Right to Buy Margaret Thatcher introduced for council tenants. It could be paid for by tax changes which would discourage people from buying up new buy-to-let properties.So fewer landlords, more homeowners.Young people just want the same chances previous generations enjoyed. So let’s build more by building smarter, and give a new generation the chance to buy a home.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: universal credit benefits boost 4k benefits
story: Around , claimants are in line for an extra £ per week when they move on to the controversial new system, which has so far been hit by a string of teething problems.Theresa May has told MPs that there are billions of pounds of unclaimed benefits sitting in a pot that will be able to be dished out automatically when Brits switch to the new system.Three million people are set to go onto Universal Credit next year as part of a staged switchover from the current benefits system.She said yesterday: There are £.billion of unclaimed benefits under the legacy system of the Labour party that will be paid to people under Universal Credit., peoplegetting the benefits they are entitled to under Universal Credit.And she added: What we see in the changes we are putting forward is encouraging people into work and making sure work pays.DWP sources told The Sun that under Universal Credit Brits might not have made an application for payments such as housing benefit - even though they may have been entitled to it.But after people are moved on to the new system it will be easier to spot whether they are entitled to more money, and can submit claims for the extra cash.An OBR report said this could be worth up to £, per family - around £ a week.It estimates that by  , , of the , will be workers who arent claiming the right amount of tax credits. The rest will be Brits who could claim more for child benefit, housing benefit, income support, jobseekers allowance or ESA.Those who are already on Universal Credit at the moment are only new claimants and are unlikely to be affected - but those who are claiming benefits on the old system and who will be rolled over soon could get a welcome boost.Department for Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey told The Sun Online: Universal Credit is a benefit system designed for the st century, replacing the old out-of-date legacy system.UC will provide more support to the most vulnerable, and helps people claim their right entitlement, helping those who may not be getting the right amount.As people move onto Universal Credit from the old system, there are around £.bn of unclaimed benefits that people will be able to access – benefiting around , people.Dave Finch, Senior Fellow at the Resolution Foundation, said: One of the key remaining advantages of Universal Credit is that by simplying the benefit system it should help families to claim all of what they’re entitled to.This would offer a welcome income boost to over half a million families, but it risks being undermined by problems where – such as the large cuts made to support for working families.The government needs to both highlight the remaining benefits of Universal Credit, and do more to deal with the signicant problems it still faces.Youll have to re-apply for your benefits again, and fill out the relevant paperwork.But after giving the DWP all your information, the new system should automatically pick up whether you are entitled to more benefits.This could include jobseekers allowance, ESA, income support, tax credits, housing benefit or child benefits.Universal Credit will roll all of these into one new monthly payment.Its thought that around , Brits will benefit from it.Roll-out of the Governments flagship welfare reform programme is expected to take place in  job centres.By , it is expected there will be a full roll out across the UK.For information about whether you can claim, visit Citizens Advice.The news will be a boost for some of the millions of people who are set to migrate over to the new system, which aims to roll several benefits into one monthly payment.But the flagship programme has been beset with issues so far, even though only a small number of the population are on it.The system has been plagued with delays and problems, and hundreds of complaints that benefits have been slashed by hundreds of pounds a month.Some were missing out on hundreds due to when their pay date fell.And one family of a boy battling cancer were so poor on Universal Credit they were forced to eat his leftover hospital food.The Sun Online revealed earlier this year the case of a disabled man born with  holes in his heart who has been denied benefits on Universal Credit - and told to get a job.Ministers have insisted that no one will be worse off going on to the new systemtheir situation doesnt change.But they will only be able to access transitional protection payments for a certain amount of time under Universal Credit.The former Tory leader attacked the Governments key welfare reforms today, saying it would lead to deep political trouble.Sir John said he was worried about how fast it was being rolled out and the way thousands were set to be worse off.He told the BBC: I am saying thatyou have people who have that degree of loss, that is not something that the majority of the British population would think of as fair.Andpeople think you have to remove yourself from fairness, then you are in deep political trouble.The poll tax - introduced in the s - proved very unpopular and led to riots and rebellions, and the fall of Margaret Thatchers government.IF youre experiencing trouble applying for your Universal Credit, or the payments just dont cover it, here are your options:Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently , or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.Yesterday ex-Prime Minister Gordon Brown made a huge intervention in the debate, calling on ministers to halt the rollout.He said that Universal Credit was forcing more kids into poverty, and demanded they rethink the entire system.Ministers say the new programme will make work pay, and will encourage more Brits into work.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fat people face most prejudice
story: The World Obesity Federation report said  per cent of of adults in the UK believed people were more likely to suffer discrimination for being overweight - more than any other category.And almost half suffered stigma and discrimination due to their weight that put them off looking for help from their GP or hospital.Johanna Ralston, chief executive of the World Obesity Federation called for better education for medical students and healthcare workers.She blasted: “People are being blamed for obesity, but decades of public health research show that obesity is complex and there are multiple causes.“Despite this, society at large continues to treat people with obesity unfairly. Stigmatising obesity undermines people’s health and makes it harder to seek support.”The Federation also called on social media companies to clamp down on weight abuse online after a snapshot poll found many social media users were using discriminatory language on sites.The research showed the impact was far reaching and damaged people’s career prospects and could lead to social isolation.Based on an academic study, the report highlighted the common the use of negative images used by media when reporting on obesity.Looking at online media in  countries, outlets in South Africa, Hong Kong and Italy were found to be the most stigmatising, but authors said all the countries examined showed some bias.The report also highlights words and phrases to avoid for the obese including “fatty”, “chubster”, “flabby”, “supersized” and “mammoth”.It said instead people should use the terms “iniduals with a high BMI” and “people living with obesity”.Ms Ralston added: “This World Obesity Day we’re calling on the media to reshape the narrative around obesity and for social media companies to clamp down on weight abuse online.“Changing the narrative around diseases and conditions can transform public perceptions and improve quality of le and outcomes for patients.“As obesity rates continue to rise, we’re also appealing to the medical education authorities and providers to improve specialist education in medical schools, as people with obesity are often dismissed by their healthcare professional because of their weight without being properly diagnosed.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain hidden debt world ranking
story: A major report by the IMF reassessed  major nations’ net worth, balancing how much each owns to each owes.Only Portugal fared worse than the UK, as it emerges the Government now has eye-watering liabilities of more than £trillion – which is more than % of our entire annual GDP.The international financial watchdog last night warned that this leaves the UK dangerously exposed to the next economic downturn.The IMF looked at every state’s assets, from land to energy resources, as well as what they are on the hook for, from pensions to stakes in banks and regular borrowing.Even previously troubled states like El Salvador, Brazil and Albania have less liabilities than Britain.Norway has the healthiest outlook because of its massive oil and gas reserves, followed closely by Russia.Britain’s new debt hole has largely been created by the financial crisis, which hit us harder than most other countries.The Labour and then Coalition governments sold off a lot of what they owned to give a short term boost to public finances.The findings in the IMF’s annual Fiscal Monitor are a major blow to Philip Hammond just a few weeks before he delivers his Budget on October .But yesterday’s monthly GDP figures gave the Chancellor a small boost, confirming the summer’s growth from extra retail sales has been maintained.The economy grew by .% in the three months to August. title: big firms ethnic minorities
story: The Prime Minister has signed up some of the UK’s biggest organisations including the Armed Forces, NHS and banks in a bid to eradicate ethnicity pay discrimination after a damning probe revealed a massive pay gap.The pledge comes a year after a damning race disparity audit revealed shocking discrimination in the workplace -
